etymologies: late Middle English (in the senses ‘contain between limits’ and ‘halt (an effect’)): from Latin intercept- ‘caught between’, from the verb intercipere, from inter- ‘between’ + capere ‘take’

definitions: obstruct (someone or something) so as to prevent them from continuing to a destination

examples.text: intelligence agencies intercepted a series of telephone calls
I intercepted Ed on his way to work

shortDefinitions: obstruct person or thing so as to prevent them from continuing to destination

definitions: (of a defensive player) catch a forward pass.
cut off or deflect (light or other electromagnetic radiation)

examples.text: a second prism can be swung in to intercept the light beam

definitions: (of a line or surface) mark or cut off (part of a space, line, or surface).
shortDefinitions: (of line or surface) mark or cut off

definitions: an act or instance of intercepting something

examples.text: he read the file of radio intercepts

shortDefinitions: act or instance of intercepting something

definitions: the point at which a given line cuts a coordinate axis; the value of the coordinate at that point.
shortDefinitions: point at which given line cuts coordinate axis
